<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 587, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 728, 634]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 313, 918, 345]]<|/det|>
The student uses a thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). Room temperature is \(22^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 357, 492, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 512, 920, 544]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into an empty beaker. She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the \(V=100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) row of Table 2.1, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 557, 918, 604]]<|/det|>
Without delay, she pours \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of cold water into the beaker. She stirs the water and measures the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water. She repeats the procedure until she has added a total of \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of cold water to the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 617, 841, 633]]<|/det|>
All the readings are shown in Table 2.1. \(V\) is the total volume of water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 646, 520, 662]]<|/det|>
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 646, 916, 662]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 673, 540, 689]]<|/det|>
Table 2.1

\(V /\)\(\theta /\)

12073
14065
16059
18054
20049

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 536, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 102, 431, 118]]<|/det|>
A ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 128, 860, 805]]<|/det|>

<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 872, 136, 888]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 872, 918, 885]]<|/det|>
· Draw a normal to the line MR that passes through the centre of MR. Label the normal NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 887, 664, 900]]<|/det|>
· Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 902, 918, 931]]<|/det|>
· Draw a line 10.0 cm long from B at an angle of incidence \(i=40^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 933, 876, 949]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 779, 88]]<|/det|>
The student places the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line MR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 511, 119]]<|/det|>
He places two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\), on line AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 917, 165]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) with crosses (X) on line AB at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 136, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 917, 228]]<|/det|>
The student views the images of pins \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. He places two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\), so that pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) are shown on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 242, 184, 258]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 885, 258]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 242, 876, 258]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 272, 184, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 917, 304]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between this line and the horizontal line MR. An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 315, 885, 331]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha = ....................................................$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 103, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 846, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 103, 420, 119]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 134, 400, 150]]<|/det|>
· wires with different diameters

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 152, 548, 164]]<|/det|>
· instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 168, 240, 180]]<|/det|>
· metre ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 184, 240, 195]]<|/det|>
· ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 199, 240, 210]]<|/det|>
· voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 214, 273, 226]]<|/det|>
· power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 242, 704, 258]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 273, 796, 289]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 297, 917, 338]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R=\frac{V}{I}\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 353, 536, 369]]<|/det|>
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 384, 224, 400]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 415, 175, 431]]<|/det|>
· draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 432, 495, 444]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 447, 485, 459]]<|/det|>
· state **one** key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 461, 917, 490]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 493, 600, 505]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.
